Here’s a book title that I was surprised to find is not hyperbole. Science really is creating new life forms. Rutherford doesn’t mean cloning life forms we know. He means altering the structure and components of DNA and coming up with odd hybrids of life—such as a goat that excretes spider web silk in its milk.The sorts of stories Rutherford tells are the ones that science fiction has often warned against, the monsters that come from the imagination of our Frankensteins. So, should we be afraid?Rutherford, a geneticist, a writer and editor of the prestigious science journal Nature, and a presenter of programs for the BBC in the United Kingdom, is not particularly worried about the gains scientists have made in creating life. He regards this as “a golden age in biology.” This book, in part, takes the time to reassure the reader that all will be well. To do so, Rutherford even contends that the world’s best-known bogeymen (think Monsanto, for example) are not empowered to wreak havoc on our planet’s future.Rutherford makes a good case for synthetic biology and synthetic genetics, but before he does, he reviews what is known about life and its origins. We take the tour of the history of life starting with the big bang and Higgs Boson (and the current experiment with the Large Hadron Collider to re-create that big bang), tour the development of the cell (and how mitochondria within cells point to a common origin of all life forms), and move through the structure of DNA, again, with a discussion of the evidence of a common origin for all life forms.In addition, what it means to be alive is defined—well, sort of. A handy definition is “Life is a process that stops your molecules from simply decaying into more stable forms.” But I do like the longer version explaining Schrodinger’s argument; “Living systems are the continual maintenance of energy imbalance. In essence, life is the maintenance of disequilibrium, and energy as life uses it is derived from this inequity. . . . The entropy of the universe is bound only to increase, thereby ultimately creating a more balanced but less ordered existence.” Sounds almost philosophical, doesn’t it?Rutherford tells the reader that “synthetic biology means different things to different people,” but explores it by looking at the world as a toolbox full of tools provided by evolution that are then available for creating new life-forms. One of the ways of creating these new life-forms is by altering DNA. DNA is shown to be a “data storage device” and scientists can now alter the available data.Interesting discussions of examples of synthetic biology include “Synthia,” a single synthetic cell created in 2010, and “Freckles” the goat, with her golden orb-weaver spider genetic code, which causes her milk to have spider silk in it. Of course, Rutherford discusses the value of these things—spider webs have important properties (they are very elastic and strong) that may be very useful in many applications.There are reasons for man to explore changes in both plant and animal life. They have to do with feeding a hungry world as less and less land is arable in a more extreme global climate, and with medical advances that will save lives. But whether you agree with Rutherford that these changes are harbingers of a golden age or whether you want everything to go back to organic, it is important to know what is happening in our world. And Creation is a good place to start finding out.High school housekeeping: I read this book partly because I am a curious creature and want to know about synthetic biology, but partly because I think it is exactly the kind of book that the designers of the Common Core are hoping you’ll read—an ‘informational text’ if you will, one that has facts that could prove very useful to you.Creation is very interesting and very informative. Rutherford’s writing is clear and he often uses analogies to language and to music to make points about science easier to understand. All of this is very helpful. So, would the average high school student pick this book up and read it, bringing delight to the lives of those Common Core Dr. Frankensteins?Well—this is a book that many high school students would be fascinated by, especially those interested in becoming researchers or doctors. But it’s not easy, despite Rutherford’s lucid style. Students who have done well in biology class will have a much easier time with the discussion of the roles and components of DNA and RNA. Though not everyone is going to follow Rutherford’s argument for synthetic biology, those who can and do will be happily enriched.NOTE: This review is also posted on my blog School Library Lady.

Super intriguing - got me really thinking about many aspects of evolution, even off the page. Reading the bibliography alone - so even theories of the origin of life on earth that are from the 50s (the Miller-Urey experiment, abiogenesis - life emerging from the primordial ooze) and now fringe ideas from the 70s (panspermia - excellently utilized in the 70s Invasion of the Body Snatchers - that bacterial life might have come from outer space - jump starting evolution by introducing the building blocks of DNA from a foreign element, usually thought to be a meteor of some sort during the Great Bombardment) have been dismissed - the majority of Rutherford's sources were coming from the last 15 years of scientific discovery - does this mean that the information age has come to rule? The internet, much like rocket science and television and telephones before it, does present a means to unite and educate the world, though now we use it for cute cat videos and a 24 hour news source that tends to utilize and Orwellian double-speak to sway the populace into compliance... The first half of Creation was what really drew me initially - Rutherford does an excellent job of illustrating how life came into existence and what makes life alive. But it is really setting up the second half of the book, with how bioengineering and biological experimenting should be allowed and that it is the future of humanity in many ways. Frankenstein - the ultimate fictional explanation of the fears and possibilities of science - comes into metaphoric display here, and Rutherford falls on the side of the pro-GMO camp here. And I have to say, his argument is convincing. The book loses me a bit when he gets into genetics and DNA - this is over my head unfortunately, and being a visual learner, I need to find a good documentary that illustrates the relationship between DNA and cells. I get that the DNA chains are what transfer code and send messages to your body in terms of how we develop over time - and that the uncoding of DNA might lead to the prevention of genetic disorders, but I need to see it. (I found something close in a documentary called Your Inner Fish which showed how one isolated gene can result in mutations like 6th fingers.) It's just over my head right now, but I understand parts of it.Also really liked the using the remix/hip-hop metaphor in illustrating the nature of evolution and existence. The building blocks already exist - they are not created out of thin air, and they have always been here. Time measures change, so in a way, the future of man has already been decided, but not in a fate/non-secular way - we are just carriers of our own genetic codes, an amazingly complicated conversation with change and time, and we are just beginning to write about it and explain it - you have the major figures of science in the 19th and 20th centuries - Darwin and Einstein - who each changed the way we view life.... Loved when Rutherford talked about language evolving and how language even mirrors general evolution - just this idea of CHANGE and the nature of humanity - birth life death - if feels like we are on the brink of a new conception of existence and the pieces are already out in the ether. Using DJ Shadow's Endtroducing as a manner of discussing scientific concepts - the relationship between art (pop music in this case) and science reminded me of Picasso and Duchamp (esp. Nude Descending a Staircase) and how their art changed as Einstein began illustrating the nature of time and space and how we perceive existence. (Timelapse and multiple exposure photography helped as well.) There's that sweet spot where philosophy, science, and art intersect - and we are on the verge of experiencing life in a "new" way - thought the idea of "new" might also need to be put through the remix blender. I see these steps in perception occurring all the time (Pale Fire anyone?) and unfortunately these goals of viewing the world as one large series of remixes, and that the differences between people (sex, race, religion, class, et al) need to become secondary to a greater sense of self and community and the relationship between the two. That's where I went when I started reading the paragraphs that got more into genetic code.

So I'm done with this book. I have a lot of nasty things to say about it: it was repetitive, badly organised, and the author is pedantic (though in the opinion of one reviewer featured on the cover, he is called erudite). It could have better served its purpose as a two part magazine article spanning 10 pages each. But the book has redeeming qualities. Superficially, it (the uk edition with two sides) has a really nice design that was quite fun getting into. As for the book's content, about half the available passages are actually pretty good, especially when he sticks to exposition rather than pontification. More than precise, these passages were evocative and imaginative. The final section on bioethics was also rather engaging. I find, however, that the author only has a superficial understanding of the issues at play, and discussions are mildly interesting at best. By contrast, people like Drew Endy and william B. Hurlbut seem to know what they are talking about. I saw them on youtube. If only these guys had written books about their areas of study, wow. Drew Endy is at Stanford and was involved in the formation of synbio as a field, starting the biobricks initiative, where genomes are standardised and made fit for engineering, and the iGEM competition, where undergrads assemble machines from the aforementioned standardised parts. Hurlbut is an MD with a theology degree who, though christian, is one of the most thoughtful intellectuals i've watched in a video in ages. Both these guys have done very deep thinking about the 'purpose' of synbio and other forms of genetic engineering, and understand the sort of teleological implication of messing with a living creature's genome. In my personal life, and as a struggle against the implications of Beckett's novels (which dissect the mind from the body), I've come to see how important a role our biological programming plays in determining us -- our morals, interactions, emotions, personalities -- more or less every edge and corner of our worlds. Transhumanism is therefore to me one of the most frightening thoughts. We already, today, live in a world so divorced from our natural biological inclinations. In some ways, our world is virtual, a cage which both locks out all primitive human hardships, and locks us into the uncomfortable status of a demigod, where we enjoy free lunches whose physical and human expense we do not even see any more. Hurlbut cites Nietzsche's point about the repugnant comfort, in which too much sugar makes all your food taste bad. The same point can be made about human beings who do not have to struggle and who live suspended in a reality where everything is, and can be, taken for granted. It's not even a problem isolated to transhumanism. What if one day, everything we need is taken care of by computers? What in god's name will we do? Well I'm sure we'd find something. I thought, however, that Asimov's answer in "the last question" was a brilliant response. In the story, what happens is that we'd never stop in the constant expansion of our dominion over matter. To the end, human beings continue to shape reality according in accordance with their desires, because such is their nature. When we reach a point of omnipotence, a swirling system of information and energy, however, we destroy the accumulation of our power and begin afresh, creating a new big bang, etc.All of this kind of reminds me of the quote from T.S Elliot, "We shall not cease from exploration, and the end of all our exploring will be to arrive where we started and know the place for the first time."So in the end, it is human nature, and human limitation, that binds us to who we are. At the very least, it is a constant that gives me, in a godless universe, a sure-footing about who I am and how I relate to the world. I simply cannot imagine a world where even that is taken away.But I get ahead of myself.Overall, I find synbio fascinating, and if it really turns out to be what it promises to be, I hope I may have been a small part of it in one way or another in the coming years.

The various cellular assemblages suggest routes for fighting disease, purifying environmental pollution, and finding new sources of energy. I see this book as instrumental to anyone that has to deal withcompanies that are in the healthcare/agriculture/pharmaceutical spaces. Enjoy!

The entropy of the universe is bound only to increase, thereby ultimately creating a more balanced but less ordered existence.” Sounds almost philosophical, doesn’t it?Rutherford tells the reader that “synthetic biology means different things to different people,” but explores it by looking at the world as a toolbox full of tools provided by evolution that are then available for creating new life-forms. One of the ways of creating these new life-forms is by altering DNA. DNA is shown to be a “data storage device” and scientists can now alter the available data.Interesting discussions of examples of synthetic biology include “Synthia,” a single synthetic cell created in 2010, and “Freckles” the goat, with her golden orb-weaver spider genetic code, which causes her milk to have spider silk in it. Of course, Rutherford discusses the value of these things—spider webs have important properties (they are very elastic and strong) that may be very useful in many applications.There are reasons for man to explore changes in both plant and animal life. They have to do with feeding a hungry world as less and less land is arable in a more extreme global climate, and with medical advances that will save lives. But whether you agree with Rutherford that these changes are harbingers of a golden age or whether you want everything to go back to organic, it is important to know what is happening in our world. And Creation is a good place to start finding out.High school housekeeping: I read this book partly because I am a curious creature and want to know about synthetic biology, but partly because I think it is exactly the kind of book that the designers of the Common Core are hoping you’ll read—an ‘informational text’ if you will, one that has facts that could prove very useful to you.Creation is very interesting and very informative. Rutherford’s writing is clear and he often uses analogies to language and to music to make points about science easier to understand. All of this is very helpful. So, would the average high school student pick this book up and read it, bringing delight to the lives of those Common Core Dr. Frankensteins?Well—this is a book that many high school students would be fascinated by, especially those interested in becoming researchers or doctors. But it’s not easy, despite Rutherford’s lucid style. Students who have done well in biology class will have a much easier time with the discussion of the roles and components of DNA and RNA. Though not everyone is going to follow Rutherford’s argument for synthetic biology, those who can and do will be happily enriched.NOTE: This review is also posted on my blog School Library Lady.

So I'm done with this book. I have a lot of nasty things to say about it: it was repetitive, badly organised, and the author is pedantic (though in the opinion of one reviewer featured on the cover, he is called erudite). It could have better served its purpose as a two part magazine article spanning 10 pages each. But the book has redeeming qualities. Superficially, it (the uk edition with two sides) has a really nice design that was quite fun getting into. As for the book's content, about half the available passages are actually pretty good, especially when he sticks to exposition rather than pontification. More than precise, these passages were evocative and imaginative. The final section on bioethics was also rather engaging. I find, however, that the author only has a superficial understanding of the issues at play, and discussions are mildly interesting at best. By contrast, people like Drew Endy and william B. Hurlbut seem to know what they are talking about. I saw them on youtube. If only these guys had written books about their areas of study, wow. Drew Endy is at Stanford and was involved in the formation of synbio as a field, starting the biobricks initiative, where genomes are standardised and made fit for engineering, and the iGEM competition, where undergrads assemble machines from the aforementioned standardised parts. Hurlbut is an MD with a theology degree who, though christian, is one of the most thoughtful intellectuals i've watched in a video in ages. Both these guys have done very deep thinking about the 'purpose' of synbio and other forms of genetic engineering, and understand the sort of teleological implication of messing with a living creature's genome. In my personal life, and as a struggle against the implications of Beckett's novels (which dissect the mind from the body), I've come to see how important a role our biological programming plays in determining us -- our morals, interactions, emotions, personalities -- more or less every edge and corner of our worlds. Transhumanism is therefore to me one of the most frightening thoughts. We already, today, live in a world so divorced from our natural biological inclinations. In some ways, our world is virtual, a cage which both locks out all primitive human hardships, and locks us into the uncomfortable status of a demigod, where we enjoy free lunches whose physical and human expense we do not even see any more. Hurlbut cites Nietzsche's point about the repugnant comfort, in which too much sugar makes all your food taste bad. The same point can be made about human beings who do not have to struggle and who live suspended in a reality where everything is, and can be, taken for granted. It's not even a problem isolated to transhumanism. What if one day, everything we need is taken care of by computers? What in god's name will we do? Well I'm sure we'd find something. I thought, however, that Asimov's answer in "the last question" was a brilliant response. In the story, what happens is that we'd never stop in the constant expansion of our dominion over matter. To the end, human beings continue to shape reality according in accordance with their desires, because such is their nature. When we reach a point of omnipotence, a swirling system of information and energy, however, we destroy the accumulation of our power and begin afresh, creating a new big bang, etc.All of this kind of reminds me of the quote from T.S Elliot, "We shall not cease from exploration, and the end of all our exploring will be to arrive where we started and know the place for the first time."So in the end, it is human nature, and human limitation, that binds us to who we are. At the very least, it is a constant that gives me, in a godless universe, a sure-footing about who I am and how I relate to the world. I simply cannot imagine a world where even that is taken away.But I get ahead of myself.Overall, I find synbio fascinating, and if it really turns out to be what it promises to be, I hope I may have been a small part of it in one way or another in the coming years.

Here’s a book title that I was surprised to find is not hyperbole. Science really is creating new life forms. Rutherford doesn’t mean cloning life forms we know. He means altering the structure and components of DNA and coming up with odd hybrids of life—such as a goat that excretes spider web silk in its milk.The sorts of stories Rutherford tells are the ones that science fiction has often warned against, the monsters that come from the imagination of our Frankensteins. So, should we be afraid?Rutherford, a geneticist, a writer and editor of the prestigious science journal Nature, and a presenter of programs for the BBC in the United Kingdom, is not particularly worried about the gains scientists have made in creating life. He regards this as “a golden age in biology.” This book, in part, takes the time to reassure the reader that all will be well. To do so, Rutherford even contends that the world’s best-known bogeymen (think Monsanto, for example) are not empowered to wreak havoc on our planet’s future.Rutherford makes a good case for synthetic biology and synthetic genetics, but before he does, he reviews what is known about life and its origins. We take the tour of the history of life starting with the big bang and Higgs Boson (and the current experiment with the Large Hadron Collider to re-create that big bang), tour the development of the cell (and how mitochondria within cells point to a common origin of all life forms), and move through the structure of DNA, again, with a discussion of the evidence of a common origin for all life forms.In addition, what it means to be alive is defined—well, sort of. A handy definition is “Life is a process that stops your molecules from simply decaying into more stable forms.” But I do like the longer version explaining Schrodinger’s argument; “Living systems are the continual maintenance of energy imbalance. In essence, life is the maintenance of disequilibrium, and energy as life uses it is derived from this inequity. . . . The entropy of the universe is bound only to increase, thereby ultimately creating a more balanced but less ordered existence.” Sounds almost philosophical, doesn’t it?Rutherford tells the reader that “synthetic biology means different things to different people,” but explores it by looking at the world as a toolbox full of tools provided by evolution that are then available for creating new life-forms. One of the ways of creating these new life-forms is by altering DNA. DNA is shown to be a “data storage device” and scientists can now alter the available data.Interesting discussions of examples of synthetic biology include “Synthia,” a single synthetic cell created in 2010, and “Freckles” the goat, with her golden orb-weaver spider genetic code, which causes her milk to have spider silk in it. Of course, Rutherford discusses the value of these things—spider webs have important properties (they are very elastic and strong) that may be very useful in many applications.There are reasons for man to explore changes in both plant and animal life. They have to do with feeding a hungry world as less and less land is arable in a more extreme global climate, and with medical advances that will save lives. But whether you agree with Rutherford that these changes are harbingers of a golden age or whether you want everything to go back to organic, it is important to know what is happening in our world. And Creation is a good place to start finding out.High school housekeeping: I read this book partly because I am a curious creature and want to know about synthetic biology, but partly because I think it is exactly the kind of book that the designers of the Common Core are hoping you’ll read—an ‘informational text’ if you will, one that has facts that could prove very useful to you.Creation is very interesting and very informative. Rutherford’s writing is clear and he often uses analogies to language and to music to make points about science easier to understand. All of this is very helpful. So, would the average high school student pick this book up and read it, bringing delight to the lives of those Common Core Dr. Frankensteins?Well—this is a book that many high school students would be fascinated by, especially those interested in becoming researchers or doctors. But it’s not easy, despite Rutherford’s lucid style. Students who have done well in biology class will have a much easier time with the discussion of the roles and components of DNA and RNA. Though not everyone is going to follow Rutherford’s argument for synthetic biology, those who can and do will be happily enriched.NOTE: This review is also posted on my blog School Library Lady.

Here’s a book title that I was surprised to find is not hyperbole. Science really is creating new life forms. Rutherford doesn’t mean cloning life forms we know. He means altering the structure and components of DNA and coming up with odd hybrids of life—such as a goat that excretes spider web silk in its milk.The sorts of stories Rutherford tells are the ones that science fiction has often warned against, the monsters that come from the imagination of our Frankensteins. So, should we be afraid?Rutherford, a geneticist, a writer and editor of the prestigious science journal Nature, and a presenter of programs for the BBC in the United Kingdom, is not particularly worried about the gains scientists have made in creating life. He regards this as “a golden age in biology.” This book, in part, takes the time to reassure the reader that all will be well. To do so, Rutherford even contends that the world’s best-known bogeymen (think Monsanto, for example) are not empowered to wreak havoc on our planet’s future.Rutherford makes a good case for synthetic biology and synthetic genetics, but before he does, he reviews what is known about life and its origins. We take the tour of the history of life starting with the big bang and Higgs Boson (and the current experiment with the Large Hadron Collider to re-create that big bang), tour the development of the cell (and how mitochondria within cells point to a common origin of all life forms), and move through the structure of DNA, again, with a discussion of the evidence of a common origin for all life forms.In addition, what it means to be alive is defined—well, sort of. A handy definition is “Life is a process that stops your molecules from simply decaying into more stable forms.” But I do like the longer version explaining Schrodinger’s argument; “Living systems are the continual maintenance of energy imbalance. In essence, life is the maintenance of disequilibrium, and energy as life uses it is derived from this inequity. . . . The entropy of the universe is bound only to increase, thereby ultimately creating a more balanced but less ordered existence.” Sounds almost philosophical, doesn’t it?Rutherford tells the reader that “synthetic biology means different things to different people,” but explores it by looking at the world as a toolbox full of tools provided by evolution that are then available for creating new life-forms. One of the ways of creating these new life-forms is by altering DNA. DNA is shown to be a “data storage device” and scientists can now alter the available data.Interesting discussions of examples of synthetic biology include “Synthia,” a single synthetic cell created in 2010, and “Freckles” the goat, with her golden orb-weaver spider genetic code, which causes her milk to have spider silk in it. Of course, Rutherford discusses the value of these things—spider webs have important properties (they are very elastic and strong) that may be very useful in many applications.There are reasons for man to explore changes in both plant and animal life. They have to do with feeding a hungry world as less and less land is arable in a more extreme global climate, and with medical advances that will save lives. But whether you agree with Rutherford that these changes are harbingers of a golden age or whether you want everything to go back to organic, it is important to know what is happening in our world. And Creation is a good place to start finding out.High school housekeeping: I read this book partly because I am a curious creature and want to know about synthetic biology, but partly because I think it is exactly the kind of book that the designers of the Common Core are hoping you’ll read—an ‘informational text’ if you will, one that has facts that could prove very useful to you.Creation is very interesting and very informative. Rutherford’s writing is clear and he often uses analogies to language and to music to make points about science easier to understand. All of this is very helpful. So, would the average high school student pick this book up and read it, bringing delight to the lives of those Common Core Dr. Frankensteins?Well—this is a book that many high school students would be fascinated by, especially those interested in becoming researchers or doctors. But it’s not easy, despite Rutherford’s lucid style. Students who have done well in biology class will have a much easier time with the discussion of the roles and components of DNA and RNA. Though not everyone is going to follow Rutherford’s argument for synthetic biology, those who can and do will be happily enriched.NOTE: This review is also posted on my blog School Library Lady.

Super intriguing - got me really thinking about many aspects of evolution, even off the page. Reading the bibliography alone - so even theories of the origin of life on earth that are from the 50s (the Miller-Urey experiment, abiogenesis - life emerging from the primordial ooze) and now fringe ideas from the 70s (panspermia - excellently utilized in the 70s Invasion of the Body Snatchers - that bacterial life might have come from outer space - jump starting evolution by introducing the building blocks of DNA from a foreign element, usually thought to be a meteor of some sort during the Great Bombardment) have been dismissed - the majority of Rutherford's sources were coming from the last 15 years of scientific discovery - does this mean that the information age has come to rule? The internet, much like rocket science and television and telephones before it, does present a means to unite and educate the world, though now we use it for cute cat videos and a 24 hour news source that tends to utilize and Orwellian double-speak to sway the populace into compliance... The first half of Creation was what really drew me initially - Rutherford does an excellent job of illustrating how life came into existence and what makes life alive. But it is really setting up the second half of the book, with how bioengineering and biological experimenting should be allowed and that it is the future of humanity in many ways. Frankenstein - the ultimate fictional explanation of the fears and possibilities of science - comes into metaphoric display here, and Rutherford falls on the side of the pro-GMO camp here. And I have to say, his argument is convincing. The book loses me a bit when he gets into genetics and DNA - this is over my head unfortunately, and being a visual learner, I need to find a good documentary that illustrates the relationship between DNA and cells. I get that the DNA chains are what transfer code and send messages to your body in terms of how we develop over time - and that the uncoding of DNA might lead to the prevention of genetic disorders, but I need to see it. (I found something close in a documentary called Your Inner Fish which showed how one isolated gene can result in mutations like 6th fingers.) It's just over my head right now, but I understand parts of it.Also really liked the using the remix/hip-hop metaphor in illustrating the nature of evolution and existence. The building blocks already exist - they are not created out of thin air, and they have always been here. Time measures change, so in a way, the future of man has already been decided, but not in a fate/non-secular way - we are just carriers of our own genetic codes, an amazingly complicated conversation with change and time, and we are just beginning to write about it and explain it - you have the major figures of science in the 19th and 20th centuries - Darwin and Einstein - who each changed the way we view life.... Loved when Rutherford talked about language evolving and how language even mirrors general evolution - just this idea of CHANGE and the nature of humanity - birth life death - if feels like we are on the brink of a new conception of existence and the pieces are already out in the ether. Using DJ Shadow's Endtroducing as a manner of discussing scientific concepts - the relationship between art (pop music in this case) and science reminded me of Picasso and Duchamp (esp. Nude Descending a Staircase) and how their art changed as Einstein began illustrating the nature of time and space and how we perceive existence. (Timelapse and multiple exposure photography helped as well.) There's that sweet spot where philosophy, science, and art intersect - and we are on the verge of experiencing life in a "new" way - thought the idea of "new" might also need to be put through the remix blender. I see these steps in perception occurring all the time (Pale Fire anyone?) and unfortunately these goals of viewing the world as one large series of remixes, and that the differences between people (sex, race, religion, class, et al) need to become secondary to a greater sense of self and community and the relationship between the two. That's where I went when I started reading the paragraphs that got more into genetic code.

So I'm done with this book. I have a lot of nasty things to say about it: it was repetitive, badly organised, and the author is pedantic (though in the opinion of one reviewer featured on the cover, he is called erudite). It could have better served its purpose as a two part magazine article spanning 10 pages each. But the book has redeeming qualities. Superficially, it (the uk edition with two sides) has a really nice design that was quite fun getting into. As for the book's content, about half the available passages are actually pretty good, especially when he sticks to exposition rather than pontification. More than precise, these passages were evocative and imaginative. The final section on bioethics was also rather engaging. I find, however, that the author only has a superficial understanding of the issues at play, and discussions are mildly interesting at best. By contrast, people like Drew Endy and william B. Hurlbut seem to know what they are talking about. I saw them on youtube. If only these guys had written books about their areas of study, wow. Drew Endy is at Stanford and was involved in the formation of synbio as a field, starting the biobricks initiative, where genomes are standardised and made fit for engineering, and the iGEM competition, where undergrads assemble machines from the aforementioned standardised parts. Hurlbut is an MD with a theology degree who, though christian, is one of the most thoughtful intellectuals i've watched in a video in ages. Both these guys have done very deep thinking about the 'purpose' of synbio and other forms of genetic engineering, and understand the sort of teleological implication of messing with a living creature's genome. In my personal life, and as a struggle against the implications of Beckett's novels (which dissect the mind from the body), I've come to see how important a role our biological programming plays in determining us -- our morals, interactions, emotions, personalities -- more or less every edge and corner of our worlds. Transhumanism is therefore to me one of the most frightening thoughts. We already, today, live in a world so divorced from our natural biological inclinations. In some ways, our world is virtual, a cage which both locks out all primitive human hardships, and locks us into the uncomfortable status of a demigod, where we enjoy free lunches whose physical and human expense we do not even see any more. Hurlbut cites Nietzsche's point about the repugnant comfort, in which too much sugar makes all your food taste bad. The same point can be made about human beings who do not have to struggle and who live suspended in a reality where everything is, and can be, taken for granted. It's not even a problem isolated to transhumanism. What if one day, everything we need is taken care of by computers? What in god's name will we do? Well I'm sure we'd find something. I thought, however, that Asimov's answer in "the last question" was a brilliant response. In the story, what happens is that we'd never stop in the constant expansion of our dominion over matter. To the end, human beings continue to shape reality according in accordance with their desires, because such is their nature. When we reach a point of omnipotence, a swirling system of information and energy, however, we destroy the accumulation of our power and begin afresh, creating a new big bang, etc.All of this kind of reminds me of the quote from T.S Elliot, "We shall not cease from exploration, and the end of all our exploring will be to arrive where we started and know the place for the first time."So in the end, it is human nature, and human limitation, that binds us to who we are. At the very least, it is a constant that gives me, in a godless universe, a sure-footing about who I am and how I relate to the world. I simply cannot imagine a world where even that is taken away.But I get ahead of myself.Overall, I find synbio fascinating, and if it really turns out to be what it promises to be, I hope I may have been a small part of it in one way or another in the coming years.

Here’s a book title that I was surprised to find is not hyperbole. Science really is creating new life forms. Rutherford doesn’t mean cloning life forms we know. He means altering the structure and components of DNA and coming up with odd hybrids of life—such as a goat that excretes spider web silk in its milk.The sorts of stories Rutherford tells are the ones that science fiction has often warned against, the monsters that come from the imagination of our Frankensteins. So, should we be afraid?Rutherford, a geneticist, a writer and editor of the prestigious science journal Nature, and a presenter of programs for the BBC in the United Kingdom, is not particularly worried about the gains scientists have made in creating life. He regards this as “a golden age in biology.” This book, in part, takes the time to reassure the reader that all will be well. To do so, Rutherford even contends that the world’s best-known bogeymen (think Monsanto, for example) are not empowered to wreak havoc on our planet’s future.Rutherford makes a good case for synthetic biology and synthetic genetics, but before he does, he reviews what is known about life and its origins. We take the tour of the history of life starting with the big bang and Higgs Boson (and the current experiment with the Large Hadron Collider to re-create that big bang), tour the development of the cell (and how mitochondria within cells point to a common origin of all life forms), and move through the structure of DNA, again, with a discussion of the evidence of a common origin for all life forms.In addition, what it means to be alive is defined—well, sort of. A handy definition is “Life is a process that stops your molecules from simply decaying into more stable forms.” But I do like the longer version explaining Schrodinger’s argument; “Living systems are the continual maintenance of energy imbalance. In essence, life is the maintenance of disequilibrium, and energy as life uses it is derived from this inequity. . . . The entropy of the universe is bound only to increase, thereby ultimately creating a more balanced but less ordered existence.” Sounds almost philosophical, doesn’t it?Rutherford tells the reader that “synthetic biology means different things to different people,” but explores it by looking at the world as a toolbox full of tools provided by evolution that are then available for creating new life-forms. One of the ways of creating these new life-forms is by altering DNA. DNA is shown to be a “data storage device” and scientists can now alter the available data.Interesting discussions of examples of synthetic biology include “Synthia,” a single synthetic cell created in 2010, and “Freckles” the goat, with her golden orb-weaver spider genetic code, which causes her milk to have spider silk in it. Of course, Rutherford discusses the value of these things—spider webs have important properties (they are very elastic and strong) that may be very useful in many applications.There are reasons for man to explore changes in both plant and animal life. They have to do with feeding a hungry world as less and less land is arable in a more extreme global climate, and with medical advances that will save lives. But whether you agree with Rutherford that these changes are harbingers of a golden age or whether you want everything to go back to organic, it is important to know what is happening in our world. And Creation is a good place to start finding out.High school housekeeping: I read this book partly because I am a curious creature and want to know about synthetic biology, but partly because I think it is exactly the kind of book that the designers of the Common Core are hoping you’ll read—an ‘informational text’ if you will, one that has facts that could prove very useful to you.Creation is very interesting and very informative. Rutherford’s writing is clear and he often uses analogies to language and to music to make points about science easier to understand. All of this is very helpful. So, would the average high school student pick this book up and read it, bringing delight to the lives of those Common Core Dr. Frankensteins?Well—this is a book that many high school students would be fascinated by, especially those interested in becoming researchers or doctors. But it’s not easy, despite Rutherford’s lucid style. Students who have done well in biology class will have a much easier time with the discussion of the roles and components of DNA and RNA. Though not everyone is going to follow Rutherford’s argument for synthetic biology, those who can and do will be happily enriched.NOTE: This review is also posted on my blog School Library Lady.

Super intriguing - got me really thinking about many aspects of evolution, even off the page. Reading the bibliography alone - so even theories of the origin of life on earth that are from the 50s (the Miller-Urey experiment, abiogenesis - life emerging from the primordial ooze) and now fringe ideas from the 70s (panspermia - excellently utilized in the 70s Invasion of the Body Snatchers - that bacterial life might have come from outer space - jump starting evolution by introducing the building blocks of DNA from a foreign element, usually thought to be a meteor of some sort during the Great Bombardment) have been dismissed - the majority of Rutherford's sources were coming from the last 15 years of scientific discovery - does this mean that the information age has come to rule? The internet, much like rocket science and television and telephones before it, does present a means to unite and educate the world, though now we use it for cute cat videos and a 24 hour news source that tends to utilize and Orwellian double-speak to sway the populace into compliance... The first half of Creation was what really drew me initially - Rutherford does an excellent job of illustrating how life came into existence and what makes life alive. But it is really setting up the second half of the book, with how bioengineering and biological experimenting should be allowed and that it is the future of humanity in many ways. Frankenstein - the ultimate fictional explanation of the fears and possibilities of science - comes into metaphoric display here, and Rutherford falls on the side of the pro-GMO camp here. And I have to say, his argument is convincing. The book loses me a bit when he gets into genetics and DNA - this is over my head unfortunately, and being a visual learner, I need to find a good documentary that illustrates the relationship between DNA and cells. I get that the DNA chains are what transfer code and send messages to your body in terms of how we develop over time - and that the uncoding of DNA might lead to the prevention of genetic disorders, but I need to see it. (I found something close in a documentary called Your Inner Fish which showed how one isolated gene can result in mutations like 6th fingers.) It's just over my head right now, but I understand parts of it.Also really liked the using the remix/hip-hop metaphor in illustrating the nature of evolution and existence. The building blocks already exist - they are not created out of thin air, and they have always been here. Time measures change, so in a way, the future of man has already been decided, but not in a fate/non-secular way - we are just carriers of our own genetic codes, an amazingly complicated conversation with change and time, and we are just beginning to write about it and explain it - you have the major figures of science in the 19th and 20th centuries - Darwin and Einstein - who each changed the way we view life.... Loved when Rutherford talked about language evolving and how language even mirrors general evolution - just this idea of CHANGE and the nature of humanity - birth life death - if feels like we are on the brink of a new conception of existence and the pieces are already out in the ether. Using DJ Shadow's Endtroducing as a manner of discussing scientific concepts - the relationship between art (pop music in this case) and science reminded me of Picasso and Duchamp (esp. Nude Descending a Staircase) and how their art changed as Einstein began illustrating the nature of time and space and how we perceive existence. (Timelapse and multiple exposure photography helped as well.) There's that sweet spot where philosophy, science, and art intersect - and we are on the verge of experiencing life in a "new" way - thought the idea of "new" might also need to be put through the remix blender. I see these steps in perception occurring all the time (Pale Fire anyone?) and unfortunately these goals of viewing the world as one large series of remixes, and that the differences between people (sex, race, religion, class, et al) need to become secondary to a greater sense of self and community and the relationship between the two. That's where I went when I started reading the paragraphs that got more into genetic code.

So I'm done with this book. I have a lot of nasty things to say about it: it was repetitive, badly organised, and the author is pedantic (though in the opinion of one reviewer featured on the cover, he is called erudite). It could have better served its purpose as a two part magazine article spanning 10 pages each. But the book has redeeming qualities. Superficially, it (the uk edition with two sides) has a really nice design that was quite fun getting into. As for the book's content, about half the available passages are actually pretty good, especially when he sticks to exposition rather than pontification. More than precise, these passages were evocative and imaginative. The final section on bioethics was also rather engaging. I find, however, that the author only has a superficial understanding of the issues at play, and discussions are mildly interesting at best. By contrast, people like Drew Endy and william B. Hurlbut seem to know what they are talking about. I saw them on youtube. If only these guys had written books about their areas of study, wow. Drew Endy is at Stanford and was involved in the formation of synbio as a field, starting the biobricks initiative, where genomes are standardised and made fit for engineering, and the iGEM competition, where undergrads assemble machines from the aforementioned standardised parts. Hurlbut is an MD with a theology degree who, though christian, is one of the most thoughtful intellectuals i've watched in a video in ages. Both these guys have done very deep thinking about the 'purpose' of synbio and other forms of genetic engineering, and understand the sort of teleological implication of messing with a living creature's genome. In my personal life, and as a struggle against the implications of Beckett's novels (which dissect the mind from the body), I've come to see how important a role our biological programming plays in determining us -- our morals, interactions, emotions, personalities -- more or less every edge and corner of our worlds. Transhumanism is therefore to me one of the most frightening thoughts. We already, today, live in a world so divorced from our natural biological inclinations. In some ways, our world is virtual, a cage which both locks out all primitive human hardships, and locks us into the uncomfortable status of a demigod, where we enjoy free lunches whose physical and human expense we do not even see any more. Hurlbut cites Nietzsche's point about the repugnant comfort, in which too much sugar makes all your food taste bad. The same point can be made about human beings who do not have to struggle and who live suspended in a reality where everything is, and can be, taken for granted. It's not even a problem isolated to transhumanism. What if one day, everything we need is taken care of by computers? What in god's name will we do? Well I'm sure we'd find something. I thought, however, that Asimov's answer in "the last question" was a brilliant response. In the story, what happens is that we'd never stop in the constant expansion of our dominion over matter. To the end, human beings continue to shape reality according in accordance with their desires, because such is their nature. When we reach a point of omnipotence, a swirling system of information and energy, however, we destroy the accumulation of our power and begin afresh, creating a new big bang, etc.All of this kind of reminds me of the quote from T.S Elliot, "We shall not cease from exploration, and the end of all our exploring will be to arrive where we started and know the place for the first time."So in the end, it is human nature, and human limitation, that binds us to who we are. At the very least, it is a constant that gives me, in a godless universe, a sure-footing about who I am and how I relate to the world. I simply cannot imagine a world where even that is taken away.But I get ahead of myself.Overall, I find synbio fascinating, and if it really turns out to be what it promises to be, I hope I may have been a small part of it in one way or another in the coming years.

Here’s a book title that I was surprised to find is not hyperbole. Science really is creating new life forms. Rutherford doesn’t mean cloning life forms we know. He means altering the structure and components of DNA and coming up with odd hybrids of life—such as a goat that excretes spider web silk in its milk.The sorts of stories Rutherford tells are the ones that science fiction has often warned against, the monsters that come from the imagination of our Frankensteins. So, should we be afraid?Rutherford, a geneticist, a writer and editor of the prestigious science journal Nature, and a presenter of programs for the BBC in the United Kingdom, is not particularly worried about the gains scientists have made in creating life. He regards this as “a golden age in biology.” This book, in part, takes the time to reassure the reader that all will be well. To do so, Rutherford even contends that the world’s best-known bogeymen (think Monsanto, for example) are not empowered to wreak havoc on our planet’s future.Rutherford makes a good case for synthetic biology and synthetic genetics, but before he does, he reviews what is known about life and its origins. We take the tour of the history of life starting with the big bang and Higgs Boson (and the current experiment with the Large Hadron Collider to re-create that big bang), tour the development of the cell (and how mitochondria within cells point to a common origin of all life forms), and move through the structure of DNA, again, with a discussion of the evidence of a common origin for all life forms.In addition, what it means to be alive is defined—well, sort of. A handy definition is “Life is a process that stops your molecules from simply decaying into more stable forms.” But I do like the longer version explaining Schrodinger’s argument; “Living systems are the continual maintenance of energy imbalance. In essence, life is the maintenance of disequilibrium, and energy as life uses it is derived from this inequity. . . . The entropy of the universe is bound only to increase, thereby ultimately creating a more balanced but less ordered existence.” Sounds almost philosophical, doesn’t it?Rutherford tells the reader that “synthetic biology means different things to different people,” but explores it by looking at the world as a toolbox full of tools provided by evolution that are then available for creating new life-forms. One of the ways of creating these new life-forms is by altering DNA. DNA is shown to be a “data storage device” and scientists can now alter the available data.Interesting discussions of examples of synthetic biology include “Synthia,” a single synthetic cell created in 2010, and “Freckles” the goat, with her golden orb-weaver spider genetic code, which causes her milk to have spider silk in it. Of course, Rutherford discusses the value of these things—spider webs have important properties (they are very elastic and strong) that may be very useful in many applications.There are reasons for man to explore changes in both plant and animal life. They have to do with feeding a hungry world as less and less land is arable in a more extreme global climate, and with medical advances that will save lives. But whether you agree with Rutherford that these changes are harbingers of a golden age or whether you want everything to go back to organic, it is important to know what is happening in our world. And Creation is a good place to start finding out.High school housekeeping: I read this book partly because I am a curious creature and want to know about synthetic biology, but partly because I think it is exactly the kind of book that the designers of the Common Core are hoping you’ll read—an ‘informational text’ if you will, one that has facts that could prove very useful to you.Creation is very interesting and very informative. Rutherford’s writing is clear and he often uses analogies to language and to music to make points about science easier to understand. All of this is very helpful. So, would the average high school student pick this book up and read it, bringing delight to the lives of those Common Core Dr. Frankensteins?Well—this is a book that many high school students would be fascinated by, especially those interested in becoming researchers or doctors. But it’s not easy, despite Rutherford’s lucid style. Students who have done well in biology class will have a much easier time with the discussion of the roles and components of DNA and RNA. Though not everyone is going to follow Rutherford’s argument for synthetic biology, those who can and do will be happily enriched.NOTE: This review is also posted on my blog School Library Lady.

Super intriguing - got me really thinking about many aspects of evolution, even off the page. Reading the bibliography alone - so even theories of the origin of life on earth that are from the 50s (the Miller-Urey experiment, abiogenesis - life emerging from the primordial ooze) and now fringe ideas from the 70s (panspermia - excellently utilized in the 70s Invasion of the Body Snatchers - that bacterial life might have come from outer space - jump starting evolution by introducing the building blocks of DNA from a foreign element, usually thought to be a meteor of some sort during the Great Bombardment) have been dismissed - the majority of Rutherford's sources were coming from the last 15 years of scientific discovery - does this mean that the information age has come to rule? The internet, much like rocket science and television and telephones before it, does present a means to unite and educate the world, though now we use it for cute cat videos and a 24 hour news source that tends to utilize and Orwellian double-speak to sway the populace into compliance... The first half of Creation was what really drew me initially - Rutherford does an excellent job of illustrating how life came into existence and what makes life alive. But it is really setting up the second half of the book, with how bioengineering and biological experimenting should be allowed and that it is the future of humanity in many ways. Frankenstein - the ultimate fictional explanation of the fears and possibilities of science - comes into metaphoric display here, and Rutherford falls on the side of the pro-GMO camp here. And I have to say, his argument is convincing. The book loses me a bit when he gets into genetics and DNA - this is over my head unfortunately, and being a visual learner, I need to find a good documentary that illustrates the relationship between DNA and cells. I get that the DNA chains are what transfer code and send messages to your body in terms of how we develop over time - and that the uncoding of DNA might lead to the prevention of genetic disorders, but I need to see it. (I found something close in a documentary called Your Inner Fish which showed how one isolated gene can result in mutations like 6th fingers.) It's just over my head right now, but I understand parts of it.Also really liked the using the remix/hip-hop metaphor in illustrating the nature of evolution and existence. The building blocks already exist - they are not created out of thin air, and they have always been here. Time measures change, so in a way, the future of man has already been decided, but not in a fate/non-secular way - we are just carriers of our own genetic codes, an amazingly complicated conversation with change and time, and we are just beginning to write about it and explain it - you have the major figures of science in the 19th and 20th centuries - Darwin and Einstein - who each changed the way we view life.... Loved when Rutherford talked about language evolving and how language even mirrors general evolution - just this idea of CHANGE and the nature of humanity - birth life death - if feels like we are on the brink of a new conception of existence and the pieces are already out in the ether. Using DJ Shadow's Endtroducing as a manner of discussing scientific concepts - the relationship between art (pop music in this case) and science reminded me of Picasso and Duchamp (esp. Nude Descending a Staircase) and how their art changed as Einstein began illustrating the nature of time and space and how we perceive existence. (Timelapse and multiple exposure photography helped as well.) There's that sweet spot where philosophy, science, and art intersect - and we are on the verge of experiencing life in a "new" way - thought the idea of "new" might also need to be put through the remix blender. I see these steps in perception occurring all the time (Pale Fire anyone?) and unfortunately these goals of viewing the world as one large series of remixes, and that the differences between people (sex, race, religion, class, et al) need to become secondary to a greater sense of self and community and the relationship between the two. That's where I went when I started reading the paragraphs that got more into genetic code.

So I'm done with this book. I have a lot of nasty things to say about it: it was repetitive, badly organised, and the author is pedantic (though in the opinion of one reviewer featured on the cover, he is called erudite). It could have better served its purpose as a two part magazine article spanning 10 pages each. But the book has redeeming qualities. Superficially, it (the uk edition with two sides) has a really nice design that was quite fun getting into. As for the book's content, about half the available passages are actually pretty good, especially when he sticks to exposition rather than pontification. More than precise, these passages were evocative and imaginative. The final section on bioethics was also rather engaging. I find, however, that the author only has a superficial understanding of the issues at play, and discussions are mildly interesting at best. By contrast, people like Drew Endy and william B. Hurlbut seem to know what they are talking about. I saw them on youtube. If only these guys had written books about their areas of study, wow. Drew Endy is at Stanford and was involved in the formation of synbio as a field, starting the biobricks initiative, where genomes are standardised and made fit for engineering, and the iGEM competition, where undergrads assemble machines from the aforementioned standardised parts. Hurlbut is an MD with a theology degree who, though christian, is one of the most thoughtful intellectuals i've watched in a video in ages. Both these guys have done very deep thinking about the 'purpose' of synbio and other forms of genetic engineering, and understand the sort of teleological implication of messing with a living creature's genome. In my personal life, and as a struggle against the implications of Beckett's novels (which dissect the mind from the body), I've come to see how important a role our biological programming plays in determining us -- our morals, interactions, emotions, personalities -- more or less every edge and corner of our worlds. Transhumanism is therefore to me one of the most frightening thoughts. We already, today, live in a world so divorced from our natural biological inclinations. In some ways, our world is virtual, a cage which both locks out all primitive human hardships, and locks us into the uncomfortable status of a demigod, where we enjoy free lunches whose physical and human expense we do not even see any more. Hurlbut cites Nietzsche's point about the repugnant comfort, in which too much sugar makes all your food taste bad. The same point can be made about human beings who do not have to struggle and who live suspended in a reality where everything is, and can be, taken for granted. It's not even a problem isolated to transhumanism. What if one day, everything we need is taken care of by computers? What in god's name will we do? Well I'm sure we'd find something. I thought, however, that Asimov's answer in "the last question" was a brilliant response. In the story, what happens is that we'd never stop in the constant expansion of our dominion over matter. To the end, human beings continue to shape reality according in accordance with their desires, because such is their nature. When we reach a point of omnipotence, a swirling system of information and energy, however, we destroy the accumulation of our power and begin afresh, creating a new big bang, etc.All of this kind of reminds me of the quote from T.S Elliot, "We shall not cease from exploration, and the end of all our exploring will be to arrive where we started and know the place for the first time."So in the end, it is human nature, and human limitation, that binds us to who we are. At the very least, it is a constant that gives me, in a godless universe, a sure-footing about who I am and how I relate to the world. I simply cannot imagine a world where even that is taken away.But I get ahead of myself.Overall, I find synbio fascinating, and if it really turns out to be what it promises to be, I hope I may have been a small part of it in one way or another in the coming years.

The second part of the book delves into the current projects in genetics, from approaches to fighting cancer, to modifying food and agricultural crops, to technologies for astronauts to use.Had I read a book like this before going to college, I would have gone into the field of cellular biology. The book highlights the ways that the work in this field is critical for solving challenges in health, energy, and the environment. Many discoveries are happening through the convergence of science and engineering using the tools of synthetic biology.The book explains how cells can be designed and bred to become part of an arsenal of biological components and tools. The various cellular assemblages suggest routes for fighting disease, purifying environmental pollution, and finding new sources of energy. I see this book as instrumental to anyone that has to deal withcompanies that are in the healthcare/agriculture/pharmaceutical spaces. The book is helpful for understanding day to day science inthe news, including concerns about genetic engineering of food, viruses, technologies, patents, etc - the reader will be in a much better place to evaluate the stories coming across the wire.These new technologies for genetic manipulation are accessible and found in many labs and schools. Groups of undergraduate students are now on teams competing to design and grow new types of cells.I am definitely going to pass this book along to my son to give him a vision of where things are going (I was surprised by how far the science has already come). Enjoy!

So I'm done with this book. I have a lot of nasty things to say about it: it was repetitive, badly organised, and the author is pedantic (though in the opinion of one reviewer featured on the cover, he is called erudite). It could have better served its purpose as a two part magazine article spanning 10 pages each. But the book has redeeming qualities. Superficially, it (the uk edition with two sides) has a really nice design that was quite fun getting into. As for the book's content, about half the available passages are actually pretty good, especially when he sticks to exposition rather than pontification. More than precise, these passages were evocative and imaginative. The final section on bioethics was also rather engaging. I find, however, that the author only has a superficial understanding of the issues at play, and discussions are mildly interesting at best. By contrast, people like Drew Endy and william B. Hurlbut seem to know what they are talking about. I saw them on youtube. If only these guys had written books about their areas of study, wow. Drew Endy is at Stanford and was involved in the formation of synbio as a field, starting the biobricks initiative, where genomes are standardised and made fit for engineering, and the iGEM competition, where undergrads assemble machines from the aforementioned standardised parts. Hurlbut is an MD with a theology degree who, though christian, is one of the most thoughtful intellectuals i've watched in a video in ages. Both these guys have done very deep thinking about the 'purpose' of synbio and other forms of genetic engineering, and understand the sort of teleological implication of messing with a living creature's genome. In my personal life, and as a struggle against the implications of Beckett's novels (which dissect the mind from the body), I've come to see how important a role our biological programming plays in determining us -- our morals, interactions, emotions, personalities -- more or less every edge and corner of our worlds. Transhumanism is therefore to me one of the most frightening thoughts. We already, today, live in a world so divorced from our natural biological inclinations. In some ways, our world is virtual, a cage which both locks out all primitive human hardships, and locks us into the uncomfortable status of a demigod, where we enjoy free lunches whose physical and human expense we do not even see any more. Hurlbut cites Nietzsche's point about the repugnant comfort, in which too much sugar makes all your food taste bad. The same point can be made about human beings who do not have to struggle and who live suspended in a reality where everything is, and can be, taken for granted. It's not even a problem isolated to transhumanism. What if one day, everything we need is taken care of by computers? What in god's name will we do? Well I'm sure we'd find something. I thought, however, that Asimov's answer in "the last question" was a brilliant response. In the story, what happens is that we'd never stop in the constant expansion of our dominion over matter. To the end, human beings continue to shape reality according in accordance with their desires, because such is their nature. When we reach a point of omnipotence, a swirling system of information and energy, however, we destroy the accumulation of our power and begin afresh, creating a new big bang, etc.All of this kind of reminds me of the quote from T.S Elliot, "We shall not cease from exploration, and the end of all our exploring will be to arrive where we started and know the place for the first time."So in the end, it is human nature, and human limitation, that binds us to who we are. At the very least, it is a constant that gives me, in a godless universe, a sure-footing about who I am and how I relate to the world. I simply cannot imagine a world where even that is taken away.But I get ahead of myself.Overall, I find synbio fascinating, and if it really turns out to be what it promises to be, I hope I may have been a small part of it in one way or another in the coming years.

Here’s a book title that I was surprised to find is not hyperbole. Science really is creating new life forms. Rutherford doesn’t mean cloning life forms we know. He means altering the structure and components of DNA and coming up with odd hybrids of life—such as a goat that excretes spider web silk in its milk.The sorts of stories Rutherford tells are the ones that science fiction has often warned against, the monsters that come from the imagination of our Frankensteins. So, should we be afraid?Rutherford, a geneticist, a writer and editor of the prestigious science journal Nature, and a presenter of programs for the BBC in the United Kingdom, is not particularly worried about the gains scientists have made in creating life. He regards this as “a golden age in biology.” This book, in part, takes the time to reassure the reader that all will be well. To do so, Rutherford even contends that the world’s best-known bogeymen (think Monsanto, for example) are not empowered to wreak havoc on our planet’s future.Rutherford makes a good case for synthetic biology and synthetic genetics, but before he does, he reviews what is known about life and its origins. We take the tour of the history of life starting with the big bang and Higgs Boson (and the current experiment with the Large Hadron Collider to re-create that big bang), tour the development of the cell (and how mitochondria within cells point to a common origin of all life forms), and move through the structure of DNA, again, with a discussion of the evidence of a common origin for all life forms.In addition, what it means to be alive is defined—well, sort of. A handy definition is “Life is a process that stops your molecules from simply decaying into more stable forms.” But I do like the longer version explaining Schrodinger’s argument; “Living systems are the continual maintenance of energy imbalance. In essence, life is the maintenance of disequilibrium, and energy as life uses it is derived from this inequity. . . . The entropy of the universe is bound only to increase, thereby ultimately creating a more balanced but less ordered existence.” Sounds almost philosophical, doesn’t it?Rutherford tells the reader that “synthetic biology means different things to different people,” but explores it by looking at the world as a toolbox full of tools provided by evolution that are then available for creating new life-forms. One of the ways of creating these new life-forms is by altering DNA. DNA is shown to be a “data storage device” and scientists can now alter the available data.Interesting discussions of examples of synthetic biology include “Synthia,” a single synthetic cell created in 2010, and “Freckles” the goat, with her golden orb-weaver spider genetic code, which causes her milk to have spider silk in it. Of course, Rutherford discusses the value of these things—spider webs have important properties (they are very elastic and strong) that may be very useful in many applications.There are reasons for man to explore changes in both plant and animal life. They have to do with feeding a hungry world as less and less land is arable in a more extreme global climate, and with medical advances that will save lives. But whether you agree with Rutherford that these changes are harbingers of a golden age or whether you want everything to go back to organic, it is important to know what is happening in our world. And Creation is a good place to start finding out.High school housekeeping: I read this book partly because I am a curious creature and want to know about synthetic biology, but partly because I think it is exactly the kind of book that the designers of the Common Core are hoping you’ll read—an ‘informational text’ if you will, one that has facts that could prove very useful to you.Creation is very interesting and very informative. Rutherford’s writing is clear and he often uses analogies to language and to music to make points about science easier to understand. All of this is very helpful. So, would the average high school student pick this book up and read it, bringing delight to the lives of those Common Core Dr. Frankensteins?Well—this is a book that many high school students would be fascinated by, especially those interested in becoming researchers or doctors. But it’s not easy, despite Rutherford’s lucid style. Students who have done well in biology class will have a much easier time with the discussion of the roles and components of DNA and RNA. Though not everyone is going to follow Rutherford’s argument for synthetic biology, those who can and do will be happily enriched.NOTE: This review is also posted on my blog School Library Lady.

I thought, however, that Asimov's answer in "the last question" was a brilliant response. In the story, what happens is that we'd never stop in the constant expansion of our dominion over matter. To the end, human beings continue to shape reality according in accordance with their desires, because such is their nature. When we reach a point of omnipotence, a swirling system of information and energy, however, we destroy the accumulation of our power and begin afresh, creating a new big bang, etc.All of this kind of reminds me of the quote from T.S Elliot, "We shall not cease from exploration, and the end of all our exploring will be to arrive where we started and know the place for the first time."So in the end, it is human nature, and human limitation, that binds us to who we are. At the very least, it is a constant that gives me, in a godless universe, a sure-footing about who I am and how I relate to the world. I simply cannot imagine a world where even that is taken away.But I get ahead of myself.Overall, I find synbio fascinating, and if it really turns out to be what it promises to be, I hope I may have been a small part of it in one way or another in the coming years.

The first part of this book introduces the reader to the field of genetics. No science background is needed to read the book - it starts with basic concepts of biology and incrementally introduces more advanced aspects of cells, proteins, viruses, and DNA. The author discusses the scientific concepts in a conversational manner, with many witty and insightful observations that make the book very readable. By the end of the first part, it was really impressive to see how many concepts in cellular biology had been covered. I felt like I had achieved a good basis for understanding articles about genetic engineering. The second part of the book delves into the current projects in genetics, from approaches to fighting cancer, to modifying food and agricultural crops, to technologies for astronauts to use.Had I read a book like this before going to college, I would have gone into the field of cellular biology. The book highlights the ways that the work in this field is critical for solving challenges in health, energy, and the environment. Many discoveries are happening through the convergence of science and engineering using the tools of synthetic biology.The book explains how cells can be designed and bred to become part of an arsenal of biological components and tools. The various cellular assemblages suggest routes for fighting disease, purifying environmental pollution, and finding new sources of energy. I see this book as instrumental to anyone that has to deal withcompanies that are in the healthcare/agriculture/pharmaceutical spaces. The book is helpful for understanding day to day science inthe news, including concerns about genetic engineering of food, viruses, technologies, patents, etc - the reader will be in a much better place to evaluate the stories coming across the wire.These new technologies for genetic manipulation are accessible and found in many labs and schools. Groups of undergraduate students are now on teams competing to design and grow new types of cells.I am definitely going to pass this book along to my son to give him a vision of where things are going (I was surprised by how far the science has already come). Enjoy!

Sometime last year, I was complaining to my sister that I have no knowledge of the latest developments in biological technology. The reason being, there were so many recent developments that I was unable to keep track of all. Then, I stumbled upon this book in a library and as I read the first few lines, I knew this was it. I absorbed each news like a thirsty child and felt enormous satisfaction upon finishing it. This is such an exciting book to read. Rutherford uses romantic language and imagery to explain difficult scientific terms and concepts. It has been a while since I have read a biology book that was not dry and hard to digest. I could feel Rutherford's enthusiasm for the field in each word and every page. It is a must read for biology-lovers and anyone who is remotely interested in biotechnology, GMOs or well..how science is currently faring.

This was quite entertaining and illuminating.. The format is a little gimmicky but I only had it as an ebook so you don't get the flip-over, opposite side of the coin effect. The first part refers to what is known about the origins of life in our planet, how this is known and how the knowledge we have about this is expanding. The second part is perhaps a little more contentious, the author is quite enthusiastic about synthetic biology and the other technologies spawned by life sciences in recent times -there is a problem of perception in some of these areas, particularly concerning genetic manipulation of crops, etc. The stance in the book is not impartial, but it is informative and almost always a good read even for someone without scientific training.

This book is probably the best non-technical introduction to cell biology and genetics I have read to date. The chapter on the origins of life is absolutely fascinating and shows that we have a long way since the primeval soup theory of the origin of life we have been brought up with. The 'mirror' chapters on biotechnology are interesting as well, but they could have gone into more detail into one of the big societal debates of our time.

All the changes in genetics, genomes, etc. will continue to make books like this interesting since progress in these fields is coming so quickly. What is life? I am not sure we have the answer to that and today's answer will change by tomorrow's advances. Some dry spots in the book, but overall fascinating information.
